title: Have any of the “revelations” from the Bible ever actually come true? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s interesting that an entire line of Biblical criticism has been spawned by ideological commitments to the contrary. “We must disprove all the prophecy in the Bible!” “Why?”“Because I’m too scared to think about the existence of the supernatural. Therefore, all the prophecies are fakes!” Given this, you will find plenty of a-historical, evidence-free claims that many prophetic parts of the Bible were written after the events in question - only because these prophecies are uncannily accurate. Daniel chapter 8, for instance. Daniel records a vision which describes a great goat which rises and conquers the whole world, even the previous powerful kingdoms. After the goat’s horn (which is a symbol of authority) is broken, it divides into four smaller horns - exactly how Alexander’s kingdom was divided among his generals. And lest there be any doubt, the angel shortly thereafter translates the vision for Daniel: “And the male goat is the kingdom of Greece. The large horn that is between its eyes is the first king. As for the broken horn and the four that stood up in its place, four kingdoms shall arise out of that nation, but not with its power.” On top of this, it is pretty widely recognized that this portion of Daniel was written exactly when it claims to have been: far, far before Alexander became king. Or there’s the example of Cyrus, who is named in Isaiah 45, written far before he comes to conquer Babylon. For those who are ideologically committed to never considering the alternative, these accurate prophecies are in themselves evidence of the falsity of prophecy. They reason to themselves that “No prophecy can be very accurate, because prophecy doesn’t exist. Therefore, that which seems to be an accurate prophecy is a fake, which proves that prophecies don’t exist.” Ah, what a wonderfully self-fulfilling prophec….I mean system of literary criticism. This is barely the tip of the iceberg. Prophecies all throughout Scripture are fulfilled in later parts of Scripture, on a regular basis. Fulfilled Prophecy Demonstrates the Divine Inspiration of Scripture Always forward, Carson
